name: hay production, Swiss integrated production, intensive | hay, Swiss integrated production, intensive | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/2919/documentation

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of hay (dry matter). The dry matter yield is 11603 kg/ha. Moisture content at storage is 12%.;;[This dataset was already contained in the ecoinvent database version 2. It was not individually updated during the transfer to ecoinvent version 3. Life Cycle Impact Assessment results may still have changed, as they are affected by changes in the supply chain, i.e. in other datasets. This dataset was generated following the ecoinvent quality guidelines for version 2. It may have been subject to central changes described in the ecoinvent version 3 change report (http://www.ecoinvent.org/database/ecoinvent-version-3/reports-of-changes/), and the results of the central updates were reviewed extensively. The changes added e.g. consistent water flows and other information throughout the database. The documentation of this dataset can be found in the ecoinvent reports of version 2, which are still available via the ecoinvent website. The change report linked above covers all central changes that were made during the conversion process.]

This activity describes the production of ventilated hay on a permanent natural meadow with a lifetime of 50 years and represents one year of cultivation on an established meadow. The inputs of mineral fertilisers and pesticides are considered. Farm manure as an organic fertiliser is only accounted for in terms of direct field emissions; all pre-processes are included in the animal production systems.


The dataset includes all machine operations and corresponding machine infrastructure and sheds. Machine operations are: fertilisation, mowing, swathing, haying, fodder loading and cold air-ventilated roughage storage for 12 months in a barn; pesticides are applied manually to single plants. This activity ends after storage of hay at the farm gate.
category: A:Agriculture, forestry and fishing/01:Crop and animal production, hunting and related service activities/011:Growing of non-perennial crops/0119:Growing of other non-perennial crops

processDocumentation.geographyDescription: Refers to a production in the Swiss plateau (lowlands <700m).
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Intensive integrated production with cold-air drying in the barn.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: Data were compiled from statistics, fertilising recommendations, documents from extension services and expert knowledge.

exchanges.description: Total amount of active substance/s of fertilisers needed for the production of 'hay, Swiss integrated production, intensive' is calculated to be circa 4.84E-03 kg. Fertiliser/s used in this dataset is/are: 'ammonium nitrate, as N', 'phosphate fertiliser, as P2O5'. The total amount of active substance/s is doubled in order to account for the packaging of the dilluted product of fertiliser/s that is/are applied. Therefore, 9.68E-03 kg of packaging for fertilisers is justified with this exchange.

Total amount of active substance/s of pesticides needed for the production of hay, Swiss integrated production, intensive is calculated to be circa 4.31E-05 kg. Pesticide/s used in this dataset is/are: '[thio]carbamate-compound'. The total amount of active substance/s is doubled in order to account for the packaging of the dilluted product of pesticide/s that is/are applied. Therefore, 8.62E-05 kg of packaging for pesticides is justified with this exchange.

exchanges.description:
The exchange has been updated from 'ammonium nitrate, as N' into 'ammonium nitrate' and therefore its amount has been scaled (multiplied) from 0.0025 kg by 2.8573 kg of 'ammonium nitrate' per kg of 'ammonium nitrate, as N'. Original comment of the exchange is: See chapter 'Yields and Inputs of hay on permanent grassland' in '01_crop production - yields & inputs CH & Europe_v1.0.pdf', section 'AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTION IN SWITZERLAND' - pdf-document on the dedicated talk page of ecoinvent (www.ecoinvent.org/documentation)
